2. Dialogue used sparingly, with narrative description carrying most of the weight.  
3. A formal tone, even during tense moments, to maintain gravity.

Story A:  
- Rich, sensory-driven descriptions dominate (“cast a golden glow,” “intricate carvings,” “shadows danced along the walls”), creating a fully immersive scene.

Story B:

- Internal monologue is minimal—aside from fleeting feelings (“unease,” “couldn’t shake the feeling”)—and doesn’t deeply explore character motivations.  

Story B only partially meets the vivid description criterion and uses more dialogue, an informal tone, and sparse internal reflection, making it a weaker fit.
